# Exercises: Introduction to pandas
By Christopher van Hoecke, Maxwell Margenot

## Lecture Link : 
https://www.quantopian.com/lectures/introduction-to-pandas

### IMPORTANT NOTE: 
This lecture corresponds to the Introduction to Pandas lecture, which is part of the Quantopian lecture series. This homework expects you to rely heavily on the code presented in the corresponding lecture. Please copy and paste regularly from that lecture when starting to work on the problems, as trying to do them from scratch will likely be too difficult.

Part of the Quantopian Lecture Series:

* [www.quantopian.com/lectures](https://www.quantopian.com/lectures)
* [github.com/quantopian/research_public](https://github.com/quantopian/research_public)

# Useful Functions
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Exercise 1
## a. Series 
Given an array of data, please create a pandas Series `s` with a datetime index starting `2016-01-01`. The index should be daily frequency and should be the same length as the data.

l = np.random.randint(1,100, size=1000)
s = pd.Series(l)

## Given an array of data, please create a pandas Series s 
## with a datetime index starting 2016-01-01. 
## The index should be daily frequency and should be the same length as the data.

new_index = pd.date_range(start='2016-01-01', periods=len(s), freq='D')
s.index = new_index
s.head()

## b. Accessing Series Elements.
- Print every other element of the first 50 elements of series `s`.
- Find the value associated with the index `2017-02-20`.

## Print every other element of the first 50 elements of series s
print s.iloc[:50]
print "\n"
## Find the value associated with the index 2017-02-20
print s[s.index == '2017-02-20']
## c. Boolean Indexing.
In the series `s`, print all the values between 1 and 3.
## In the series s, print all the values between 1 and 3.
print s[(s.values > 1) & (s.values < 3)].values
print s[(s.values > 1) & (s.values < 3)]

#Exercise 2 : Indexing and time series. 
###a. Display
Print the first and last 5 elements of the series `s`.

## Print the first element of the series s
print s.iloc[0]
print "\n"
## Print the last 5 elements of the series s.
print s.iloc[-5:]

### b. Resampling
- Using the resample method, upsample the daily data to monthly frequency. Use the median method so that each monthly value is the median price of all the days in that month.
- Take the daily data and fill in every day, including weekends and holidays, using forward-fills.

symbol = "CMG"
start = "2012-01-01"
end = "2016-01-01"
prices = get_pricing(symbol, start_date=start, end_date=end, fields="price")

## Using the resample method, upsample the daily data to monthly frequency
## Use the median method so that each monthly value is the median price of all the days in that month
monthly_prices = prices.resample('M').median()
print monthly_prices.head(10)

## Take the daily data and fill in every day, including weekends and holidays, using forward-fills
calendar_dates = pd.date_range(start=start, end=end, freq='D', tz='UTC')
calendar_prices = prices.reindex(calendar_dates, method='ffill')
calendar_prices.head(31)

#Exercise 3 : Missing Data
- Replace all instances of `NaN` using the forward fill method. 
- Instead of filling, remove all instances of `NaN` from the data.

## Replace all instances of NaN using the forward fill method
prices_nan_median = calendar_prices.fillna(method='bfill')
print prices_nan_median.head()

## Instead of filling, remove all instances of NaN from the data
prices_nan_dropped = calendar_prices.dropna()
print prices_nan_dropped.head()

# Exercise 4 : Time Series Analysis with pandas
## a. General Information
Print the count, mean, standard deviation, minimum, 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles, and the max of our series s.

print "Summary Statistics"
## Print the count, mean, standard deviation, 
## minimum, 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles, and the max of our series s
print s.describe()

## b. Series Operations
- Get the additive and multiplicative returns of this series. 
- Calculate the rolling mean with a 60 day window.
- Calculate the standard deviation with a 60 day window.

data = get_pricing('GE', fields='open_price', start_date='2016-01-01', end_date='2017-01-01')

## Additive returns of the series.
returns_add = data.diff()
## Multiplicative returns of the series.
returns_mult = data.pct_change()[1:]

# Rolling mean

## Rolling mean with a 60 day window, price 
rolling_mean_price = data.rolling(window=60).mean()[59:]
rolling_mean_price.name = "60-days rolling mean of price, GE"
## Rolling mean with a 60 day window, additive returns 
rolling_mean_returns_add = returns_add.rolling(window=60).mean()[59:]
rolling_mean_returns_add = "60-days rolling mean of additive returns, GE"
## Rolling mean with a 60 day window, multiplicative returns
rolling_mean_returns_mult = returns_mult.rolling(window=60).mean()[59:]
rolling_mean_returns_add = "60-days rolling mean of multiplicative returns, GE"

# Rolling Standard Deviation

## Rolling standard deviation with a 60 day window, price 
rolling_std_price = data.rolling(window=60).std()[59:]
rolling_std_price.name = "60-days rolling std of price, GE"
## Rolling standard deviation with a 60 day window, additive returns
rolling_std_returns_add = returns_add.rolling(window=60).std()[59:]
rolling_std_returns_add = "60-days rolling std of additive returns, GE"
## Rolling standard deviation with a 60 day window, multiplicative returns
rolling_std_returns_mult = returns_mult.rolling(window=60).std()[59:]
rolling_std_returns_mult = "60-days rolling std of multiplicative returns, GE"

# Exercise 5 : DataFrames
## a. Indexing
Form a DataFrame out of `dict_data` with `l` as its index.

text/plain:
a  b         c
third   1  L  0.418691
second  2  K  0.214854
fourth  3  J  0.452513
fifth   4  M  0.656664
first   5  Z  0.616369

source: data_df

## b. DataFrames Manipulation
- Concatenate the following two series to form a dataframe. 
- Rename the columns to `Good Numbers` and `Bad Numbers`. 
- Change the index to be a datetime index starting on `2016-01-01`.

s1 = pd.Series([2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13], name='prime')
s2 = pd.Series([1, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10], name='other')

## Concatenate the following two series to form a dataframe
concat = pd.concat([s1,s2], axis=1)
## Rename the columns to Good Numbers and Bad Numbers
concat.columns = ["Good Numbers", "Bad Numbers"]
## Change the index to be a datetime index starting on 2016-01-01
concat.index = pd.date_range(start='2016-01-01', periods=len(concat))

text/html:
Good Numbers Bad Numbers
2016-01-01 2 1
2016-01-02 3 4
2016-01-03 5 6
2016-01-04 7 8
2016-01-05 11 9
2016-01-06 13 10

source: concat

# Exercise 6 : Accessing DataFrame elements.
## a. Columns
- Check the data type of one of the DataFrame's columns.
- Print the values associated with time range `2013-01-01` to `2013-01-10`.

symbol = ["XOM", "BP", "COP", "TOT"]
start = "2012-01-01"
end = "2016-01-01"
prices = get_pricing(symbol, start_date=start, end_date=end, fields="price")
if isinstance(symbol, list):
    prices.columns = map(lambda x: x.symbol, prices.columns)
else:
    prices.name = symbol

# Check Type of Data for these two.    
prices.XOM.head()
prices.loc[:, 'XOM'].head()

## Checking dtype of prices.XOM data
print prices.XOM.dtype
## Checking dtype of prices.loc[:, 'XOM'] data
print prices.loc[:, 'XOM'].dtype

## Print the values associated with time range 2013-01-01 to 2013-01-10
print prices[(prices.index >= '2013-01-01') & (prices.index <= '2013-01-10')]
## Better approach
print prices.loc['2013-01-01':'2013-01-10']

# Exercise 7 : Boolean Indexing
## a. Filtering.
- Filter pricing data from the last question (stored in `prices`) to only print values where:
    - BP > 30
    - XOM < 100
    - The intersection of both above conditions (BP > 30 **and** XOM < 100)
    - The union of the previous composite condition along with TOT having no `nan` values ((BP > 30 **and** XOM < 100) **or** TOT is non-`NaN`).
- Add a column for TSLA and drop the column for XOM.

# Filter the data for prices to only print out values where
# BP > 30
print prices[prices.BP > 30].head()
# XOM < 100
print prices[prices.XOM < 100].head()
# BP > 30 AND XOM < 100
print prices[(prices.BP > 30) & (prices.XOM < 100)].head()
# The union of (BP > 30 AND XOM < 100) with TOT being non-nan
print prices[((prices.BP > 30) & (prices.XOM < 100)) | ~prices.TOT.isnull()].head()

# Add a column for TSLA and drop the column for XOM
TSLA_price = get_pricing('TSLA', start_date=start, end_date=end, fields='price')
prices['TSLA'] = TSLA_price
prices = prices.drop('XOM', axis=1)
prices.head()

## b. DataFrame Manipulation (again)
- Concatenate these DataFrames.
- Fill the missing data with 0s

# Concatenate these dataframes
df_1 = get_pricing(['SPY', 'VXX'], start_date=start, end_date=end, fields='price')
df_2 = get_pricing(['MSFT', 'AAPL', 'GOOG'], start_date=start, end_date=end, fields='price')

concat = pd.concat([df_1, df_2], axis=1)
concat.head()
concat.columns = ['SPY','VXX','MSFT','AAPL','GOOG']
# Fill  missing data with 0
concat.fillna(0, inplace=True)
concat.head()

# Exercise 8 : Time Series Analysis
## a. Summary
- Print out a summary of the `prices` DataFrame from above.
- Take the log returns and print the first 10 values.
- Print the multiplicative returns of each company.
- Normalize and plot the returns from 2014 to 2015.
- Plot a 60 day window rolling mean of the prices.
- Plot a 60 day window rolling standfard deviation of the prices.
# Print a summary of the 'prices' times series.
prices.describe()

# Take the log returns and print the first 10 values
log_returns = pd.DataFrame(np.log(prices[1:].values / prices[:-1].values), 
                           columns=['BP','COP','TOT','TSLA'])

date_index = pd.date_range(start='2012-01-04', periods=len(log_returns))
log_returns.index = date_index

log_returns[:10]

# Print the Muliplicative returns 
returns = prices.pct_change()[1:]
returns.head()

# Normalize and plot the returns from '2014-01-01':'2015-01-01'
returns_constraint = returns.loc['2014-01-01':'2015-01-01']
z = (returns_constraint - returns_constraint.mean()) / returns_constraint.std()
plt.plot(z)
plt.legend(['BP','COP','TOT','TSLA'], loc='best');

# Plot a 60 day window rolling mean of the prices.
rolling_mean = prices.rolling(window=60).mean()[59:]

#Plot a 60 day window rolling standard deviation of the prices.
rolling_std = prices.rolling(window=60).std()[59:]

# Plotting 
plt.plot(rolling_mean)
plt.legend(['BP','COP','TOT','TSLA'], loc='best');

Congratulations on completing the Introduction to pandas exercises!
